This suggests that the damage is likely to be in a structure that provides rotational stability rather than anterior-posterior stability. The fact that the patient does not have instability at 90 degrees of flexion suggests that the posterior cruciate ligament (C) is intact or damaged minimally, as it provides most of its stability at this angle.

The patient's symptoms are consistent with rotatory instability, which is often caused by damage to the posterolateral pa of the anterior cruciate ligament (A). This is supported by the fact that the patient has a history of playing hockey, which can cause rotational injuries to the knee joint.
